Transcription for 1764656

So we're recording now. So my name is Paul Hunt and I work for Man Cap Cymru and could
you introduce yourself please? My name is Joe Powell. I work for All Wales People First.
I'm on the autism spectrum and I lived in autism care for 11 years. And where do you
live at the moment? At the moment I live in Newport in South Wales. So obviously we've
interviewed you before under very different circumstances. Could you tell me a little
bit about what you've been up to for the last seven months? What's really interesting is
I've been working from home an awful lot. Now usually the organisation I work for, All
Wales People First, we got rid of our offices a long time ago so I didn't think it would
be much of a challenge. But I was really, really surprised because just going out to
meetings a lot doesn't happen anymore. So everything is obviously home base now. Now
in one of the interviews I did before, and I'm not sure if this was used on the film,
one of the interviews I did before with you, I was talking about how if there was a nuclear
war or a nuclear holocaust I wouldn't miss anybody and I'd be okay on my own. And I think
what I've learnt over these seven months is that I actually do need people. Maybe not
need people in the way other people need people. But actually, you know, no man is an island.
And okay, it's been easier for me than your average bear. And it's easier for me than
most people. But actually, it's had a bigger toll on me than I thought. Although I would
say largely I've been unaffected compared to most people. So I think it was a massive
learning curve for me. So in a nutshell, all I've done is just work from home. That's it.
Has it affected the way that you've accessed any social groups or not even groups necessarily
individuals you would have met up with in your spare time?
Yeah, it's really affected in a few ways, positives and negatives. The negatives obviously
are there is not physical interface. One of the members I usually meet up with and we
have a got friends and we have a meal and we do some shopping that couldn't happen.
But we've actually done more member engagement because of this. In the past, for instance,
people were learning disabilities if we were to put an idea to zoom or teams to them, they
would just turn it down and flatly refuse. I think it's a no, we can't do that. That's
not a thing. So we never went there. We always did things physically because of zoom. So
because of the COVID-19 situation, I think there's been an element of the necessities
the mother of invention. People have been forced to come out of their comfort zone and
learn things like zoom because if they don't, they're not going to be able to mix with people
and have any social interaction. And because of that, I actually think during these times,
we've got more we've got more engagement with members now than we've ever done before.
And do you think if things return back to normal, you'll do things the way you used
to or do you think you might continue online just because there's so many more people involved?
I personally would like to get a mixture of the two things. I think I think definitely the person
thinks good at regular intervals, but at the same time, you know, just so there's a human contact
and that's good for certainly for staff team morale. And I think members need to be together
in a place so they can feel that physical connection. But I think in terms of resources
and time, the fact that we've been able to do stuff on zoom that we wouldn't have dreamed before.
Also, there are times when I think it would be lovely just to have, say,
team meetings and other meetings online as well. One of the benefits, for start, you cut out the
travel time, especially people live in different parts of Wales. One of the major benefits
of of this kind of technology as well. Oh, I lost my thread then I'm so sorry.
That's all right. There was a major benefit, which I'm trying to think of this technology.
Oh, we go back to sorry, I'll just take you while I get my thread.
You're asking, would we go back? So that's a positive we can connect with more people. Oh,
yeah, yeah, yeah. Another problem we're having is with our national council in terms of physical
meetings. So our national council is our member led forum across Wales, where we bring all reps
from all counties to one place to hold me to account as chief executive and set our strategy.
There are some parts of Wales where people could have an impact on their benefits. If they seem to
travel independently, might not be able to get to our physical meetings. Now that was in the past,
a real problem for us. And before Covid, we were already looking at how do we make this happen? How
do we get people to meetings that they can't attend? We looked at one of those hubs, you know,
those Amazon hubs. Yeah. We look at those portals. But since this look at it, Zoom,
we've now realized it's much easier to do this now. It's not ideal. But if say we do go to
North Wales and people from the South can't get there, we can beam them in. If we're in the South
and people from the North can't get there, we beam them in. So it gives us that flexibility,
which we didn't have before. And so thinking away from your role in your personal life,
how has it affected how you communicate with friends or family?
It's really strange because I don't really communicate with friends or family very often
anyway, because I am such a loner. But it's still affected me an awful lot. And it's affected me in
a way you wouldn't imagine. I have more social contact now than ever before since Zoom. And this
is because of the Covid situation. Meetings, meetings that would happen quarterly, and now
were happening for a long time weekly. And then there were subgroup meetings to that and prep
meetings. So it actually put a lot of pressure on me. And I found interacting as a person with
autism online under that format, excruciatingly painful to the point where at times I just wasn't,
I was being spoken over and what have you. And I've got to be honest, in one meeting,
I really lost my temper. And I really put my foot down and said, I'm on the autism spectrum,
have some consideration. Which I hated, because I don't want to do that. I don't want to,
I'm not ashamed to have autism, but I just want to appear like any other chief exec, any other
employee of an organisation. But I got into that situation where I really got upset and annoyed.
So in terms of participation, it's harder because of Zoom, unless people hand up through the chair.
It's a nightmare for me, because I need to see the social cues. But also, I have more meetings now
than I ever did by a country mile on Zoom. And that stifles me and my ability to do stuff I really
need to do for the job. So it's actually put a lot of pressure on me in that response. And of course,
when the social things don't happen as well as I thought, I then doubt myself, I doubt my position,
I doubt who I am. Am I really qualified to do this job? So it's had a negative impact on my well-being.
There's no doubt about it. But I'd say not because of lack of social contact, but because of too much
of it. So do you think if you were the kind of person to talk to friends and family often, do you
think that and your job, how do you think you would cope with that? With my family, I never
saw them much anyway, but I used to video conference them once a week. So that was dead
straightforward. I think that wouldn't be an issue for me, to be honest. You know what I mean? With
the friends and family, I don't think, no, I never really went out with people much anyway.
And when I did, it was only over the telephone if we spoke. And if we did go out to be like once a
quarter or something, very rare. So I remember you said at the start of our conversation that you
were surprised that, you know, you thought you couldn't, you could do without the contact and
you now find that you need it. Do you think that will change how you approach things when we are
allowed to interact with people again? I think I won't change how I approach things, but I think
I'll appreciate more when I am with people, when I'm not always wanting to be there or there's times
when I'm thinking, God, I wish I could just work from home. I've become more aware of how sometimes
you just need to be around people sometimes, because sometimes just being with a person and
having a positive conversation in person can just make you feel positive. You can come back.
So there's times I'll go out for a meeting, say at 10 o'clock in the morning, and we don't have our
offices. So I go to another organization, have a meeting. But if that meeting just goes quite well,
or it goes okay, or a point of view you've expressed has been understood or respected,
you go home and think about yourself, you know, and you've broken the deal by being out. So when
you do come home and do admin, just that hour or two out makes a big difference to your well-being
when you come back, because you've had some interaction. And I think it's made me more
appreciative of that. And I think I've done a lot of self-reflection. And I do sometimes wonder,
now with hindsight, when I keep saying I don't need people, I don't need people,
maybe I do need people, maybe I've always needed people. Maybe the problem has been for me,
as somebody who was non-verbal for years and had a lot of problems with my autism and Asperger's,
maybe I've just learned or I've been forced in a position where I was socially isolated so much,
that it just became the norm. And I was out of the loop so much that it became my new normal.
And maybe with hindsight, it's not that I don't need people. Maybe with hindsight,
it is more the fact that I've just lost the ability to know how to deal with,
to work with people. And I've lost the ability to know what I've lost out on.
Mm-hmm. That's an interesting viewpoint. I suppose we've touched on this a little bit,
but do you think it's affected your well-being, being either locked out or at least
physically distancing from people? I think it's definitely affected my well-being in terms of
the overload of information. So I'm not just doing my job, but there's constant emails,
constant chats, follow-up actions. It's definitely done that. That makes me more aware of being on
the autism spectrum, being different to my peers. That makes me doubt myself more. So I think there's
definitely been all that going on from a selfish point of view. I think absolutely that has
certainly affected me. I think I've got away with it more than most people in the grand scheme of
things. I've actually been very, very lucky, luckier than the vast majority of people I'd say.
But yeah, it really has impacted for those reasons. Yeah, I'd say for those reasons.
So you're talking to me today from your sofa. Do you have a workspace at home?
I have an office in my house upstairs, and the internet's rubbish. So I end up sitting on the
sofa and doing work there. The problem is I always used to just work all day anyway,
so I didn't really have much of a social boundary. I think now it's even less so with me working from
home because I'm constantly working, whereas before, at least if you're on the train,
going somewhere, you know, you might have 10 minutes to yourself to think, or what have you.
Now I'm not even doing that really. You might break for something to get back. So you end up
doing a lot more hours. Productivity's massive. Has it changed your relationship with your
home and your living area? Do you see it now as one thing, or was it always like that?
I think for me it was always like that anyway because even when I used to come home,
when I did go to meetings, I would still sit down and do loads of works and send emails out.
I think work's my hobby as well, which is very tragic. But I think it is. And so actually when
I come home in an evening, when my hours are done, I'll put the telly on in the background
and what have you because I like that feeling of being at home. But I can't just sit and watch
the television anyway. I'd have to be doing something. So in that respect, no, I don't think
it's made much of a difference. So do you talk to anyone at the moment, like a friend or maybe a
family member, about not just the pandemic but everyday life? No, I don't think I do, to be honest.
I talk to staff mostly and that's on everyday work stuff or I help them with their problems. But
no, very rarely, to be honest. I speak to my parents once a week online because they've now

There's a lady called Yvonne Boxall who used to do my job in the past before we give it to somebody
with lived experience. And I check in with her now and again if I'm worried. So I say once a week,
I call her and I check in with her and that's normally about, is this normal? Is this normal?

We get on well anyway because we just see things very similarly in terms of the third sector.
And I think over a period of time she's been able to get to know me. I think as well the fact that
she comes from a learning disability background as a support worker. She was a special education

So with Yvonne do you listen to her concerns or you know does she chat to you about things
